4.2. Renewal. The Agreement may be renewed upon mutual written consent at least 90 days prior to the expiration of the Term. Renewal shall be subject to renegotiation of payment terms and other material elements of this Agreement.

Any material breach by either Party shall permit the non-breaching Party to terminate this Agreement upon providing a thirty (30) days’ written notice of the breach to the breaching Party. 8.2. Duration of Confidentiality. 8.3. Exceptions. 9. PERFORMANCE BENCHMARKS AND QUALITY ASSURANCE
9.1. Milestone Payment Schedule. Licensee agrees to adhere to performance benchmarks as set forth in Exhibit B. Payments made under Section 5.4 are contingent upon Licensee achieving specific benchmarks as detailed therein. Failure to achieve such benchmarks shall trigger a review of the installment amounts and potentially result in adjustments as determined by a joint committee.

9.2. Quality Assurance Reviews. The Parties shall, on an annual basis, conduct quality assurance reviews to assess the performance and compatibility of the Licensed Materials with Licensee’s products. The results of such reviews shall be documented in writing and reviewed by both Parties.

10. AUDIT RIGHTS AND COMPLIANCE
10.1. Audit. Licensor shall have, upon giving at least thirty (30) days written notice, the right to audit Licensee’s records and systems to ensure compliance with the terms of this Agreement. The audit rights provided herein are in addition to any other rights reserved by Licensor in any other section that refers to record keeping.

10.2. Remediation. If an audit uncovers material non-compliance by Licensee, Licensee shall promptly correct such deficiencies within thirty (30) days upon receiving written notice from Licensor. PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT

This PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT (the “Agreement”) is made and entered into as of April 1, 2023 (the “Effective Date”), by and between Alpha Ventures LLC, a limited liability company organized under the laws of the State of New York with its principal place of business at 123 Wall Street, New York, NY 10005 (hereinafter referred to as "Partner A"), and Beta Innovations Inc., a corporation organized under the laws of the State of Delaware, with its principal office located at 456 Market Street, Wilmington, DE 19801 (hereinafter referred to as "Partner B"). Partner A and Partner B shall hereinafter be collectively referred to as the “Partners” or individually as a “Partner.”

RECITALS

WHEREAS, the Partners desire to establish a business partnership for the purpose of developing, marketing, distributing, and selling innovative technological solutions (the "Business"); and

WHEREAS, the Parties wish to define their respective rights, duties, obligations, and liabilities with respect to the Business as provided herein;

NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual covenants and promises contained herein and for other good and valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which are hereby acknowledged, the Partners agree as follows:

1. DEFINITIONS

   1.1. "Business" means the joint operations as defined in this Agreement, including but not limited to operation, manufacture, marketing, and sale of technological products and services. 
   1.2. "Confidential Information" means all non-public information disclosed by one Party to the other, regardless of format, that is designated as confidential or that reasonably should be understood to be confidential under the circumstances. 
   1.3. "Effective Date" means the date set forth in the preamble above. 
   1.4. "Intellectual Property" means patents, trademarks, copyrights, trade secrets, and other proprietary rights, whether registered or unregistered.
   1.5. "Net Profits" means the gross revenue received minus any agreed operating, administrative, and other ordinary business expenses as explicitly provided herein.

2. SCOPE OF THE BUSINESS

   2.1. Purpose. The primary objective of the partnership is to collaborate in the research, development, commercialization, and distribution of advanced technological solutions, specifically in the sectors of digital innovation, green energy technology, and software development.
   2.2. Exclusivity. Both Partners agree that during the term of this Agreement, neither may undertake any endeavor that competes directly with the Business without prior written consent from the other Partner.
   2.3. Territorial Scope. The Business activities covered under this Agreement shall be conducted worldwide, subject to any local regulatory requirements.

3. PARTNERSHIP CAPITAL AND CONTRIBUTIONS

   3.1. Initial Capital. The Partners agree to contribute capital in the following proportions:
       (a) Partner A shall contribute $500,000 USD in cash and in-kind resources (technical equipment and proprietary software licenses).
       (b) Partner B shall contribute $750,000 USD in cash as well as human resources, market research data, and distribution networks.
   3.2. Additional Contributions. Additional funding may be provided on a need basis, subject to mutual written agreement, and will not alter the respective percentage ownership unless otherwise specified in subsequent amendments.
   3.3. Ownership Interests. Each Partner’s initial ownership interest shall be determined by their respective contributions, with Partner A holding approximately 40% and Partner B approximately 60% of the equity rights in the Business. Notwithstanding the foregoing, certain sections of this Agreement may refer to ownership on an equal basis for decision-making purposes.

4. MANAGEMENT AND GOVERNANCE

   4.1. Management Committee. A Management Committee composed of two designated representatives from each Partner shall oversee the day-to-day operations, strategic planning, and major financial decisions regarding the Business.
   4.2. Voting. Decisions by the Management Committee require a majority vote. For decisions affecting the core operational strategy, a unanimous vote is required. In instances where the vote is tied, the matter shall be deferred to mediation as described in Section 9. 
   4.3. Duties and Responsibilities. 
       a. Partner A shall manage research and development, product innovation, and the procurement of technological tools.
       b. Partner B shall oversee marketing, sales, distribution, and overall customer relations. 
       c. Both Parties will collaborate on product launch strategies, intellectual property development, and investor relations. However, further in the document, there is an expectation that Partner A share overall strategic decision-making duties equally with Partner B, which may conflict with the above provisions.

5. FINANCIAL MATTERS

   5.1. Revenue Sharing. Net Profits of the Business shall be distributed monthly based on the following schedule:
       (a) Partner A shall receive 35% of the Net Profits; 
       (b) Partner B shall receive 65% of the Net Profits.
   5.2. Payment Terms. 
       a. All payments disbursed to the Partners shall be calculated quarterly and distributed within ten (10) days of the close of the quarter.
       b. In Section 5.3, it is however stated that all profit distributions shall occur on a monthly basis, with payments processed within fifteen (15) days after month-end, thereby potentially causing ambiguity regarding frequency and timing of payments.
   5.3. Expense Reimbursements. Partners shall be reimbursed for direct expenses incurred in relation to Business operations upon presentation of detailed receipts. Reimbursement shall be carried out within thirty (30) days from the receipt of valid supporting documentation.
   5.4. Audit Rights. Either Partner may request an independent audit of the Business’s financial records once per fiscal year. The audit costs shall be borne equally by both Partners, unless significant discrepancies arise wherein the non-defaulting Partner may demand reimbursement for audit fees.

6. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY

   6.1. Ownership of Pre-Existing Intellectual Property. Each Partner shall retain sole ownership of any Intellectual Property that was developed or acquired prior to the Effective Date. 
   6.2. Jointly Developed Intellectual Property. Intellectual Property developed jointly during the term of this Agreement shall be jointly owned by the Partners. Notably, however, Section 8.5 later purports that all Intellectual Property arising from collaboration shall be solely owned by Partner B, except where explicitly stated otherwise in a separate addendum. This divergence creates a potential conflict regarding intellectual property ownership rights.
   6.3. Licensing Rights. Both Partners grant each other a non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use the joint Intellectual Property in connection with the Business operations for the duration of this Agreement.
   6.4. Protection and Enforcement. Each Partner is responsible for enforcing and defending their own Intellectual Property rights. In cases of infringement, the Partners shall collaborate to take appropriate legal action.

7. CONFIDENTIALITY AND NON-DISCLOSURE

   7.1. Confidential Information Handling. Both Partners agree to maintain strict confidentiality of all Confidential Information obtained in the course of the partnership. 
   7.2. Duration of Confidentiality. The confidentiality obligations shall survive the termination of this Agreement for a period of five (5) years following the termination date.
   7.3. Exceptions. Information that is publicly available, was independently developed without breach of this Agreement, or is required to be disclosed by law, shall not be subject to these confidentiality restrictions. In Section 10.2, however, it is suggested that the confidentiality obligations extend indefinitely for certain highly sensitive materials, thereby introducing a subtle inconsistency concerning the duration of confidentiality obligations.

8. TERM AND TERMINATION

   8.1. Term. This Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date and, unless earlier terminated as set forth herein, continue for an initial term of five (5) years.
   8.2. Renewal. Upon expiry of the initial term, this Agreement shall automatically renew for successive one-year terms unless either Partner provides written notice of intent not to renew at least sixty (60) days prior to the expiration of the then-current term.
   8.3. Termination for Cause. Either Partner may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice to the other if there is a material breach of any provision herein which is not cured within thirty (30) days after receiving written notice thereof.
   8.4. Termination Without Cause. Either Partner may elect to terminate this Agreement without cause subject to the following conditions:
       (a) Termination must be provided with a notice period of no less than thirty (30) days; however, Section 11.1 later mandates a sixty (60) day notice period under certain conditions, resulting in an internal contradiction regarding the required notice period. 
       (b) All outstanding financial obligations must be settled within ninety (90) days from the effective date of termination.
   8.5. Post-Termination Rights. Upon termination, each Partner shall have a non-transferable, revocable license to use the Business-related Intellectual Property and Confidential Information solely for the purpose of winding down ongoing operations. As stated in Section 6.2, disputes may arise concerning exclusive ownership of Intellectual Property developed during the partnership and thus the actual rights post-termination may become ambiguous.

9. DISPUTE RESOLUTION

   9.1. Negotiation. In the event of any dispute arising between the Partners in connection with or relating to this Agreement, the Parties shall first attempt to resolve such dispute amicably through good faith negotiations.
   9.2. Mediation. Should negotiations fail to resolve the dispute within thirty (30) days, the dispute shall be submitted to mediation under the rules of the American Arbitration Association. The mediation shall be held in New York unless mutually agreed otherwise.
   9.3. Arbitration. If the dispute is not resolved by mediation within sixty (60) days, the same dispute shall then be finally resolved by binding arbitration in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association. Notably, Section 9.4 below dictates a different mechanism for dispute resolution for contract breaches related to confidentiality claims, which may result in differing forms of resolution being available.
   9.4. Confidential Dispute Resolution. In disputes solely regarding breaches of confidentiality obligations, the Partners agree to resolve such issues exclusively through litigation in the courts of Delaware. This provision may conflict with the arbitration procedure outlined in Sections 9.2 and 9.3.

10. REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES

   10.1. Mutual Representations. Each Partner represents and warrants that it has the full capacity, power, and authority to enter into this Agreement and fully perform its obligations hereunder; that entering into this Agreement does not violate any other agreement or law; and that any Information or data provided to the other Partner is accurate and complete.
   10.2. Non-Infringement. Each Partner warrants that the performance of their obligations will not infringe upon or misappropriate any Intellectual Property right of any third party.
   10.3. Authority. The individuals executing this Agreement on behalf of each Partner are duly authorized to bind their respective organizations. Any documents or communications referencing their authority shall be given full faith and credit in all proceedings.

11. MISCELLANEOUS

   11.1. Governing Law. This Agreement shall be construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the State of New York. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Section 9.4 dictates that disputes concerning confidentiality shall be litigated in Delaware, creating a jurisdictional ambiguity which must be resolved by the courts.
   11.2. Amendments. This Agreement may be amended or modified only by a written document executed by both Partners. The amendment process shall require unanimous consent from the Management Committee.
   11.3. Entire Agreement. This Agreement, together with any exhibits, schedules, and addenda attached hereto, represents the entire understanding between the Partners regarding the subject matter hereof and supersedes all prior negotiations, understandings, or agreements between the Partners, whether written or oral.
   11.4. Severability. If any term or provision of this Agreement is found to be invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions of this Agreement shall remain in full force and effect.
   11.5. Notices. All notices or communications required or permitted to be given under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given if delivered personally, or transmitted via email, facsimile, or certified mail (return receipt requested) to the addresses set forth above or to such other address as may be designated by notice.
   11.6. Force Majeure. Neither Partner shall be liable for any delay or failure in performance of any obligation under this Agreement due to causes beyond its reasonable control, including but not limited to acts of God, war, terrorism, government regulations, or market disruptions.
   11.7. Waiver. No waiver of any breach of any term or condition hereof shall be deemed a waiver of any subsequent breach of the same or any other term or condition, whether similar or dissimilar.
   11.8. Assignment. Neither Partner shall assign or otherwise transfer its rights or obligations under this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party, except that either Partner may assign this Agreement to a successor entity in connection with a merger or sale of substantially all of its assets.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties hereto have executed this Partnership Agreement on the day and year first above written.

FOR ALPHA VENTURES LLC:
_________________________________________
Name: Jonathan Michaels
Title: Managing Director
Date: April 1, 2023

FOR BETA INNOVATIONS INC.:
_________________________________________
Name: Samantha Lee
Title: Chief Executive Officer
Date: March 15, 2023

APPENDIX A: ADDITIONAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS

A.1. Special Covenants. The Partners agree that any additional obligations will be negotiated in good faith in future addenda. Nothing in this Appendix shall override the provisions of Sections 6.2 and 11.1.

A.2. Insurance and Indemnity. Each Partner shall maintain adequate insurance coverage for risks arising out of their respective contributions to the Business. Indemnification limits as detailed under the financial terms are subject to a cap of $1,000,000 for direct claims; however, under certain circumstances described later in addendum attachments, the cap may increase to $2,000,000, thus leading to potential uncertainty in indemnification obligations.

A.3. Dispute Escalation. Prior to initiating any of the dispute resolution procedures in Section 9, the Management Committee shall meet at least once every quarter for a formal review session to raise and resolve any emerging concerns. The minutes of such meetings shall be maintained and referenced in future dispute resolutions.

A.4. Confidentiality of Negotiations. All discussions regarding potential amendments or addenda to this Agreement shall be treated as Confidential Information, subject to the confidentiality obligations established in Section 7. However, as noted earlier in Section 7.3, the duration of such obligation may inconsistently extend indefinitely for select categories of information.

A.5. Miscellaneous Provisions. The Partners acknowledge that this Agreement is a complex instrument intended to capture the breadth of their collaborative intentions. In the event that any internal inconsistencies arise, the Parties agree to negotiate in good faith to ameliorate the effect of such contradictions, though such negotiations shall not be deemed a waiver of any rights under this Agreement.

[End of Agreement]
known_contradictions: Conflicting Payment Terms: Section 5.1 specifies quarterly distribution of Net Profits with payments made within 10 days after quarter-end, while Section 5.3 mandates monthly distributions with payments processed within 15 days after month-end, leading to ambiguity regarding the consistent schedule of profit distributions.

Conflicting Intellectual Property Ownership: Section 6.2 provides for joint ownership of Intellectual Property developed during the partnership, whereas Section 8.5 states that all Intellectual Property arising from the collaboration shall be solely owned by Partner B, except as otherwise provided in addenda. This creates uncertainty regarding the actual ownership structure.

Contradictory Termination Notice Periods: Section 8.4(a) requires a 30-day notice period for termination without cause, yet Section 11.1 later stipulates conditions that necessitate a 60-day notice period under certain circumstances, generating a potential conflict in the termination procedure.

Conflicting Confidentiality Duration: Section 7.2 establishes a confidentiality obligation for 5 years after termination, but Section 7.3 implies that, for certain highly sensitive information, confidentiality obligations may extend indefinitely, leading to potential disputes on confidentiality duration.

Inconsistent Governing Law and Dispute Resolution: Section 11.1 designates New York law as the governing law for this Agreement, while Section 9.4 mandates that disputes related solely to confidentiality be litigated in Delaware. This creates a jurisdictional ambiguity regarding which state’s laws and venue govern different aspects of disputes under this Agreement.

text:
{
  "contract": "NON-DISCLOSURE AGREEMENT

This NON-DISCLOSURE AGREEMENT (the “Agreement”) is entered into by and between:

(1) GLOBAL TECH DISCLOSURES, INC., a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of Delaware with its principal place of business at 123 Innovation Way, Wilmington, DE 19801 (hereinafter referred to as the “Disclosing Party”); and

(2) BRIGHT IDEAS SOLUTIONS, LLC, a limited liability company organized and existing under the laws of the State of Delaware with its principal place of business at 789 Enterprise Plaza, Dover, DE 19901 (hereinafter referred to as the “Receiving Party”).

Collectively referred to as the "Parties" and individually as a "Party." 

RECITALS

WHEREAS, the Disclosing Party possesses certain proprietary and confidential information relating to its business, technology, and operations; and

WHEREAS, the Receiving Party is willing to receive such confidential information for the sole purpose of evaluating a potential business relationship and/or undertaking specific collaborative projects (the "Permitted Purpose").

NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual covenants and promises contained herein, and for other good and valuable consideration, the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged, the Parties agree as follows:

SECTION 1 – DEFINITIONS

1.1 "Confidential Information" shall mean all technical and non-technical information, including without limitation, data, designs, processes, trade secrets, know-how, research, business plans, financial data, projections, customer lists, pricing information and other proprietary information disclosed by the Disclosing Party either directly or indirectly, in writing, orally, or by inspection of tangible objects. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Confidential Information shall not include any information that (i) is or becomes generally available to the public other than as a result of disclosure by the Receiving Party; (ii) was within the possession of the Receiving Party prior to receipt from the Disclosing Party; (iii) is obtained by the Receiving Party without a breach of this Agreement from a third party with lawful access; or (iv) is independently developed by employees of the Receiving Party who had no access to such information.

1.2 "Term" means the duration of this Agreement as provided in Section 3 below.

1.3 "Effective Date" means the date on which this Agreement is signed by the last Party executing it, as set forth in Section 18.

SECTION 2 – PURPOSE

2.1 The Parties agree that the Confidential Information disclosed under this Agreement shall be used solely for the Permitted Purpose.

SECTION 3 – TERM AND TERMINATION

3.1 This Agreement shall commence as of the Effective Date and remain in effect for a period of five (5) years (the “Term”). Notwithstanding Section 3.1 and elsewhere in this Agreement, certain obligations regarding confidentiality shall survive termination as specified in Section 10.

3.2 Either Party may terminate this Agreement by providing thirty (30) days prior written notice to the other Party. Termination of this Agreement shall not relieve either Party of its confidentiality obligations hereunder as set forth in Section 10.

3.3 Early termination shall not affect any accrued rights or obligations, except that any payments, fees, or penalties due prior to termination shall survive in accordance with the terms of Sections 6 and 7.

SECTION 4 – SCOPE OF DISCLOSURE

4.1 The Disclosing Party shall disclose Confidential Information only to those of its employees, consultants, and agents who are bound by similar confidentiality obligations and only to the extent necessary to accomplish the Permitted Purpose.

4.2 The Receiving Party agrees to restrict disclosure of Confidential Information within its organization to its directors, officers, employees, and approved consultants having a need to know and shall not disclose the Confidential Information to any third party without obtaining the prior written consent of the Disclosing Party.

SECTION 5 – OBLIGATIONS OF THE RECEIVING PARTY

5.1 The Receiving Party agrees:
    (a) To maintain the Confidential Information in strict confidence and to exercise at least the same degree of care in safeguarding the Confidential Information as it does with its own confidential information, but in no event less than a reasonable degree of care;
    (b) Not to disclose or disseminate the Confidential Information to any third party except as permitted in this Agreement;
    (c) To use the Confidential Information solely for the Permitted Purpose;
    (d) To make no copies of the Confidential Information unless required by the nature of the Permitted Purpose; and
    (e) To notify the Disclosing Party immediately upon discovery of any unauthorized use or disclosure of Confidential Information.

5.2 The Receiving Party’s responsibility for safeguarding Confidential Information is subject to any instructions provided by the Disclosing Party. However, in Section 11 below, the Receiving Party is similarly required to contribute to documenting and preserving proprietary rights, creating an ambiguity regarding central responsibility in the event of a data breach.

SECTION 6 – PAYMENT TERMS

6.1 In consideration of the disclosure of Confidential Information, the Receiving Party agrees to pay the Disclosing Party a fee of USD 1,000 per month. This payment is due on the first calendar day of each month commencing on the Effective Date.

6.2 Late payments shall incur a penalty of 2% per month on the outstanding balance.

6.3 Payment adjustments or revisions shall be made only in writing and executed by both Parties. This section shall survive termination of this Agreement with regards to any outstanding payment obligations.

SECTION 7 – FEES, EXPENSES, AND OTHER FINANCIAL TERMS

7.1 Notwithstanding Section 6, for certain projects outlined in Attachment A of this Agreement, the Receiving Party agrees to a modified fee schedule of USD 1,200 per month. In such cases, any delays beyond a grace period of fifteen (15) days shall incur additional penalties calculated at a rate of 3% per month on the outstanding balance.

7.2 The Parties agree that any additional out-of-pocket costs incurred as a direct result of the performance under this Agreement shall be reimbursed by the Receiving Party upon presentation of valid documentation.

7.3 In the event of a dispute regarding any fees or expenses, the Parties agree to resolve such dispute by engaging in mediation as described in Section 16.

SECTION 8 – CONFIDENTIALITY OBLIGATIONS

8.1 The Receiving Party agrees that the Confidential Information shall remain confidential for a period of three (3) years from the termination of this Agreement. The parties acknowledge, however, that certain sections herein (specifically Section 10) mandate a five (5) year confidentiality period, creating a potential ambiguity regarding the duration of confidentiality obligations.

8.2 Except as otherwise provided herein, no disclosure to third parties shall be made without the prior written consent of the Disclosing Party.

8.3 The Receiving Party shall ensure that any person receiving Confidential Information has executed a written agreement with confidentiality provisions substantially similar to those contained herein.

SECTION 9 – INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS

9.1 All original intellectual property and improvements thereto made solely by the Disclosing Party remain the exclusive property of the Disclosing Party.

9.2 Notwithstanding Section 9.1, should any derivative works be jointly developed by the Parties pursuant to the Permitted Purpose, the Receiving Party shall have a non-exclusive, royalty-free license for internal use only. This creates a subtle conflict concerning the ownership and licensing of jointly developed intellectual property.

9.3 The Receiving Party shall not reverse engineer, disassemble, or decompile any Confidential Information provided under this Agreement.

SECTION 10 – SURVIVAL OF CONFIDENTIALITY OBLIGATIONS

10.1 The provisions of this Agreement relating to the definition of Confidential Information and the obligations of confidentiality shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of five (5) years following the termination date, except that the survival period set forth in Section 8.1 (three years) shall govern with respect to public disclosures.

10.2 It is expressly agreed that even after termination or expiration of this Agreement, no Party shall use or disclose Confidential Information except as provided in subsection 10.1.

SECTION 11 – INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY CONTRIBUTIONS

11.1 In the event that any intellectual property is jointly created by the Parties during the term of this Agreement, such intellectual property shall be owned jointly by the Parties, regardless of the relative degree of contribution. This joint ownership is intended solely for collaborative efforts and does not extend to pre-existing intellectual property.

11.2 Should any disputes arise regarding the contributions or ownership of jointly developed intellectual property, the Parties agree that such disputes shall be resolved pursuant to the mechanisms set forth in Section 16 below.

SECTION 12 – DATA SECURITY AND RECORDKEEPING

12.1 Both Parties agree to maintain current procedures for controlling access to and safeguarding Confidential Information in electronic and physical formats. This includes, but is not limited to, password-protected systems, secure storage facilities, and access logs.

12.2 The Receiving Party shall, upon request, provide the Disclosing Party with written confirmation of its compliance with the data security measures outlined in this Section.

12.3 Notwithstanding the obligations herein, conflicting responsibilities emerge between Section 5.1 and Section 11 regarding maintenance and documentation of secure storage, leading to ambiguity over which Party bears the ultimate responsibility in instances of data compromise.

SECTION 13 – REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES

13.1 Each Party represents and warrants that it has the legal right and authority to enter into this Agreement and that the performance of its obligations hereunder does not violate any applicable law or regulation or any agreement to which it is a party.

13.2 The Disclosing Party makes no representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of the Confidential Information, and the Receiving Party agrees that the Disclosing Party shall have no liability to the Receiving Party resulting from the use of the Confidential Information.

13.3 The Receiving Party further represents and warrants that all individuals having access to the Confidential Information on its behalf have been informed of and agree (in writing when possible) to confidentiality obligations at least as protective as those contained herein.

SECTION 14 – GOVERNING LAW

14.1 This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of New York, without regard to its conflict of law rules.

14.2 In the event of any dispute arising under or in connection with this Agreement, such dispute shall, as a first resort, be resolved via mediation pursuant to Section 16.

SECTION 15 – ASSIGNMENT

15.1 Neither Party may assign any of its rights or delegate any of its obligations under this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party, except in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale of substantially all of its assets.

15.2 Any purported assignment in violation of this Section shall be null and void.

SECTION 16 – DISPUTE RESOLUTION

16.1 In the event of a dispute arising out of or relating to this Agreement, the Parties agree to first try to resolve the dispute through informal negotiation.

16.2 If the dispute has not been resolved within thirty (30) days of the commencement of negotiations, the Parties agree to submit the dispute to mediation in the State of California under the then-current rules of mediation promulgated by a recognized mediation body. This mediation clause conflicts with the governing law provision in Section 14, which calls for New York law, thereby creating a potential jurisdictional ambiguity.

16.3 Should mediation fail to resolve the dispute, the Parties shall submit to arbitration in accordance with the rules and procedures of the American Arbitration Association. The decision of the arbitrator shall be final and binding.

SECTION 17 – NOTICES

17.1 All notices, requests, consents, claims, demands, waivers, and other communications under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been given: (i) when delivered by hand (with written confirmation of receipt); (ii) when received by the addressee if sent by a nationally recognized overnight courier (with written confirmation of receipt); or (iii) on the date sent by email or facsimile if sent during normal business hours on a business day, or on the next business day if sent after normal business hours.

17.2 Notices shall be addressed to the parties as follows (or to such other address as a party may designate by notice to the other Party in accordance with this Section):

For the Disclosing Party:
Global Tech Disclosures, Inc.
123 Innovation Way
Wilmington, DE 19801
Email: legal@globaltechdisclosures.com

For the Receiving Party:
Bright Ideas Solutions, LLC
789 Enterprise Plaza
Dover, DE 19901
Email: contracts@brightideassolutions.com

SECTION 18 – MISCELLANEOUS

18.1 This Agreement constitutes the entire understanding between the Parties regarding the subject matter hereof and supersedes any prior agreements, understandings, or representations, whether oral or written.

18.2 In the event that any provision of this Agreement is held to be invalid or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions of this Agreement shall remain in full force and effect.

18.3 This Agreement may be executed in counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original, but all of which together shall constitute one and the same instrument.

18.4 The Parties acknowledge that certain definitions provided in Section 1 (such as the definition of Confidential Information excluding publicly available data) are not entirely consistent with the usage in subsequent sections (e.g., Section 8 which appears to include such data under certain circumstances), thereby introducing a latent ambiguity in the interpretation of what constitutes Confidential Information.

18.5 The Parties agree that any dispute not resolved through the procedures stated herein shall be resolved in a manner that is mutually agreeable, and that both Parties will negotiate in good faith to achieve a resolution.

18.6 This Agreement shall be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties and their respective successors and permitted assigns.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF,
